reviewText:
The premise of this game is deceptively simplistic - killing your character couldn't be that hard, could it? Well, apparently it can be.

Pros:

+Beautiful game aesthetic (the screenshots are spot-on)
+Increasingly difficult puzzles that make you feel nice and smart for solving them
+Fresh concept
+Tight controls
+Elements of humour
+Cards

Cons:

-No current resolution options (full-screen distorts play beyond what appears to be 8x6)
-Some progression bugs
-No key-mapping

Neutral:

+/- Controls, while tight, are very simplistic - literally only side to side and jump
+/- Music - standard fair
+/- Fantastic amounts of trial & error
+/- Some truly sinister levels (1.5 is not bugged, it can be solved)

This game has a lot to offer despite some minor issues here and there, and a bit of patching is sure to bring out its full potential (as the company responsible for the ever popular 'Hero Siege' you can expect them to do a nice job of polishing their creation). I'd say give it a go while it's on sale, or wait a few weeks while the kinks are worked out.

reviewText:
To put it simply: This game has no idea what it wants to be.
The premise is a very unique and interesting- It's a puzzle platformer where the goal is to kill yourself. You play as a pig whose parents were sent to a slaughterhouse, so to reunite with them in animal heaven, you must use up all of your lives. Very bizarre, and the puzzles are decent at first, but halfway through the first level, they throw trick solutions at you that you have absolutely no way of knowing about.

Beyond that, though, this doesn't even stay a puzzle game. There are sections where the goal is to not die, and instead, you have to chase down a key through Super Meat Boy-esque areas. The key gets you farther along, eventually to a boss, which you must kill and, again, not die to. The bosses certainly don't factor in to the story, and they certainly don't fit the parameters the game already set up (Namely, the goal of dying).

So we're looking at a casual puzzle / intense precision platformer game- Two genres that are really at odds with each other. Unfortunately for the precision platformer moments, the movement is binary- You're either moving, or you're not. This leads to some punishing situations, if you lightly tap one direction or the other, and it is something that Super Meat Boy did a fantastic job of mitigating. In addition to that, the edge detection on blocks is unreliable, at best- There are numerous times where I've fallen before reaching the edge of a block, and other times where I've been able to jump a bit after I should have fallen. This makes any precision jumping an absolute nightmare.

And then there are the gimmicks. Now, this isn't a bad term. All games use gimmicks. Portal's gimmick was, well, portals, and it worked astoundingly well. But Squishy here just uses too many of them. Halfway through the first chapter, you'll discover that the only solution to a puzzle is by wrapping around the screen; a function that is rarely used since then. Towards the end, there will be a level where you can fly- No preamble, no use afterwards, you can just fly for that one level. For one of the boss fights, you can suddenly throw fireballs (Which is explained by a textbox right before, saying You can temporarily use the power of fire!")

reviewText:
Squishy the Suicidal Pig - the game sparks interest as soon as you read the name! And the experiences I had with it are unbeatable for that price!
It's a funny puzzle platformer from the creators of Hero Siege. You are a pink piglet with an yellow sweater, that made a deal with the devil - The devil is bored and wants Squishy to die 31 times for his entertainment and if Squishy achieves that, the devil will kick him out of hell into heaven to his parents. Soo, I said to myself, how hard can it be to die in this game? Turns out - hard :)
The levels are designed with love and thought and I found myself thinking hard right after the first 4 or 5. The music is decent, unintrusive and in tone with the cheerful graphics of the game.
The controls are tight and responsive and my universal cheap gamepad is working. I'm not exactly a fan of the momentum in jumping for those kind of games, but this one uses it wisely and reasonably.
I would love to be able to view the hilarious intro again, but I haven't found a way to do it.
Beside the story mode, there is a speedrun one (you need to beat the game to unlock it), an extra game where you try to survive as long as u can (my record is 46sec) and like 5 different hats to get by completing actually kinda hard objectives - beat the game, gather all secrets, gather all apples and so on...
As you progress in the game, your object will change and you will have to try to survive, speedrun trough levels to shoot down a bird and what not!
I would say this game is definitely worth the price and with the current discount is actually a bargain - speedruns, achievements, trade cards ... can recommend wholeheartedly!

When Angels Deserve To Die - An Official Waffle King Review
~Find more here.[www.nonm.co.uk]

Suicide is never the answer. Never. No matter what your circumstances are, you must persevere. You must go on. Things will get easier with time, and you will survive. Not even if you were accidentally born with a cow for a head. Not a cow's head, but a whole cow. That'd be really uncomfortable. But is that worth taking your life over? Think of all the milk you could make. Or if you really have to sneeze and it just won't come out? This too shall pass. Though you may be in insufferable agony, a soul tempered within the flames of Hell shines brighter. Cleansed of sin in hellfire, you are stronger, purer, and have a will stronger than clamshell packaging.


But this game gives the wrong idea.


Squishy The Suicidal Pig just makes it that easy, huh? Just kill yourself, and everything will be okay again? Huh? That's not a good life lesson, Squish. You're teaching these kids terrible things. Squish might not have it easy, selling his cheap little puzzle platformer for 99 cents on Steam and on the Google Play Store just to make ends meet. And his parents died, and he's in literal Hell for killing himself. But does he really have to kill himself again?


Like the game clearly says in the title, you are a squishy pig. And your goal in each level is to die. There will be many puzzles impeding your progress, but you need to figure out how to manipulate the objects in order to kill yourself. I'll admit, it's an interesting gameplay mechanic. It's not something that's seen too often. Although it has been done before. Better, even.


Right off the bat, it's easy to tell that Squish is not quite a high budget title. It looks like something you'd play for free on your school computer instead of working on your PowerPoint presentation on wolves or chlamydia or whatever you're researching.


As if the dollar price tag hid the fact that this is a cheaply-made game. At the very least it's not ugly, the spritework is nice and there's some decent animation. Like how Squish is just sweating nonstop as he idles, which seems very fitting for a suicidal pig in a sweater. The soundtrack can be a little grating, but it's mostly tolerable.


But Squish's so-called claim to fame is his excellent gameplay. Clever puzzles and platforming. This is what Squish is staking it all on. They clearly know that they're low-budget, they wouldn't be charging pocket change for the game if they thought they created a piece of art. They're hoping to skate by on quality mechanics and charm.


Much like everything else in Squish's life though, this is all a lie. Squishy is definitely charming, I'll give him that. But his game is muddled by sloppy physics and garbage puzzle design. Not to mention a clear lack of identity.


Squish will jump from puzzle platformer that requires you to die, to a Super Meat Boy-esque platformer hell that asks you to survive every few levels. Which would be perfectly fine if the controls were built for platforming. But no, Squish's movements are so imprecise. Not to mention buggy. I've had to restart puzzles multiple times because it wouldn't register that I was walking off a cliff, and I was just levitating in space as I walked off. Or my jump button suddenly losing functionality when I really needed to jump. The controls are responsive most of the time, but that's not good enough in a game that requires tight controls and twitch jumping.


I'd be more forgiving on the controls if the game at least copied everything that made Super Meat Boy great, instead of just saying Oh

reviewText:
Squishy the Suicidal Pig is a game with a cool premise, but the major flaw of it is the game just doesn't know what it wants to be and sometimes doesn't even function properly.

Basically, the game is supposed to be a puzzle platformer with a goal not to survive, but to find a method how to KILL yourself in that level instead. Sounds good, but it only manages to keep that promise for just a few first levels. The game will then ask you NOT to die, but instead to survive. And that pretty much goes for a majority of the levels after that, breaking the cool premise game had at the beggining.

Next thing, HITBOXES! Everything has a terrible hitbox around them. Even your character will sometimes fall out of the platform while standing around edges, even though you could clearly see yourself standing right on it. Same thing goes for bosses. During the first boss level, an infinite amount of crates will be falling at you from the skyes, giving you only seconds to react to them. Due to poor hitboxes, you never know if you are in a safe distance from them or not. This results in a complete frustration, when you got killed from a falling crate while standing two metres from it.

As I said, the game just doesn't know what it wants to be. To me, I think it wants to be another Super Meat Boy clone. And while the game has checkpoint system, you are not allowed to die even once per level (at least not it the first level, when the checkpoint system is introduced). The game was designed to beat in a one go, but with all the flaws game has, it's completely impossible. You die, you have to start from the begginning (replaying can take you 15-20 minutes to get to your previous position).

Summary:
+ good idea for a puzzle platformer
+ nice artstyle and backgrounds

- jumping and platforming
- later levels require you to survive, breaking the main game mechanic
- pushing blocks around could have been improved a little
- hitboxes
- mediocre and repetitive soundtrack

6/10

reviewText:
No other video game has unleashed my creativity like Squishy the Suicidal Pig. I've spent countless hours chipping away at blocks, gathering the necessary materials to complete the next masterpiece that would otherwise only occupy my mind's eye. I've also spent just as many hours exploring, spelunking and slashing my way through monsters with bravado. My character ‚Äì my entire Squishy the Suicidal Pig world ‚Äì constantly evolves into whatever I want it to be. I tell my own stories, I write my own destiny and I bring my fantasies to life one brick at a time.

However, Squishy the Suicidal Pig is yet another Mario Kart clone, as it presents cartoonish racing competition headlined by colorful mascot characters; here, the personified Red, Green, Yellow, Orange and Blue chocolate candies most recognized from their series of television commercials from the past several years. The moderate star power of the candy characters is the most impressive thing to be found in this package, which is a sad reality that sets you up well to be disappointed in every other area of the game.

At the very least, it provides blistering firefights and brilliantly crafted worlds to have them in. In fact, the exceptional caliber of its moment-to-moment gameplay is what partially excuses the fact that it never quite realizes its grand design. For as fun as it is, Squishy the Suicidal Pig just doesn't fully commit to all of its disparate parts, making it simultaneously many different things, and none of them at all.

Of course, it wouldn‚Äôt be a Squishy the Suicidal Pig game without elaborate setpieces, fierce shootouts, and tense stealth missions, and Squishy delivers some of the most memorable experiences in the series. I felt genuine dread as the ground and buildings collapsed around me during orbital weapons strikes, the zero-gravity spectacle of the Federation‚Äôs space station ambush is awe-inspiring, and bursting through a highrise window as the entire building crumbles during the Federation Day mission is exhilarating.

After the letdown of Madden 25 last year, Squishy the Suicidal Pig feels like a mostly fresh start for the series. The increased emphasis on defensive play, a great new play-calling system, and the return of long-time favorites makes this year‚Äôs Squishy one of the best in recent memory, even if it could still use work in regards to its stale commentary and longstanding bugs. As a lifelong Squishy and football fan, I‚Äôm impressed. This year‚Äôs game is both exciting and reassuring that EA Sports isn‚Äôt wasting opportunities to improve the series.

Pros

+Great with friends

Cons

Long story short: Squishy: The Suicidal pig is a brilliant puzzle-platformer with brain-crunching puzzles during it's best moments, but a horribly frustrating mess with bad controls during it's worst.

This game promises to be a 2D puzzle-platformer with an exciting twist: instead of trying to stay alive, like you do in most games, you must help the depressed pig Squishy to commit suicide. That sounds a lot easier than it actually is. There are multiple ways of taking your own life, varying from jumping into spikes all the way to building complex traps in order to drop wooden crates on yourself. What's consistent throughout the game, however, is that you have to solve increasingly difficult puzzles in order to be able to commit suicide. And some of those puzzles are really well made.

Especially during the earlier parts of the game you'll be playing levels that initially look impossible, but slowly unravel themselves as having very simple (but not so obvious) solutions. I really enjoy the solving the problems that are presented to Squishy. All elements in these levels have a function and those stages are some of the best parts of Squishy: The Suicidal pigs. Somehwat more common than those well-thought out levels, however, are levels that are purely made to frustrate, with many elements that don't seem to have a function and solutions that are so far-fetched that they take much of the fun out of the game. They're still kind of nice to play, but they feel unsatisfactory if you know how beautifully this game shines during it's better parts.

Much, much worse are the platforming levels (luckily there aren't many of them). Instead of trying to kill yourself like you do in the 'regular' levels, here you have to find a key in order to pass through a gate. Most of these levels are very difficult, not because of the well thought-out puzzles but because of the careful timing that's required. That wouldn't be much of a problem if it weren't for Squishy: The Suicidal Pig's sloppy controls. During the puzzle levels, you hardly notice the significant delay between your input and Squishy's reaction, but it becomes terribly frustrating during the platforming parts. To make things even worse, you sometimes have to finish these already difficult level in a (very) limited amount of time.

What's also kind of disappointing is the unpolished nature of this game. While the graphics are pixelated, I think they're quite charming and I don't really have much to say about it. However, the soundtrack of this game is just plain bad. It sounds like a MIDI-file and I turned it off after the first level. What really disappointed me is how lazily the devs have ported this game. The game constantly refers to console buttons that you can't use on your keyboard and you can't use your mouse. Well, actually you can use your mouse, but not in a way that's intended; you can teleport to about everywhere by right-clicking. I think it's a debugging feature that they forgot to remove and it isn't much of an issue if you have to discipline to resist abusing it, but it's still disappoingting that the devs were too lazy to remove it.

Luckily, Squishy: The Suicidal Pig is a really decent game when you look past the platforming levels and it's unpolished nature. The game offers some nice gimmicks besides the main campaign as well. reviewText:
You ever play Karoshi Suicide Salaryman? It's a series of free flash puzzle platformers where the goal is to jump into spikes or drop a box on your head, since the objective of the game is actually to kill yourself! It's a neat little game, with several bite-size levels to keep you satisfied the way Warioware does. The graphics aren't great and feel like they're fresh out of those way-too-edgy late 90s flash videos, but they're serviceable and do their job. I have fond memories of those games, so when I saw this game was on sale for just over a freakin' quarter and was mechanically similar, I figured why not.

Graphics and soundtrack are the only things this game does better than the Karoshi Suicide Salaryman series. Credit where credit is due, it's a pretty good-looking game. It isn't pandering to the retro aesthetic that so many pixelated modern games do, and I appreciate that. There's also a fair amount of effort put into this game, and a substantial amount of levels for the price. There's even a speedrun mode, which is nice to have even if I'd never use it.

Unfortunately, that doesn't change the fact that playing this game is a chore. The controls are archaic - you press up to jump instead of having a dedicated jump button separate from your movement buttons. It's a little thing but you get thrown off every once in a while. It's difficult, and not in the way a game like Dark Souls or Castlevania is difficult. Think I Wanna Be The Guy or something that's unfairly hard in an attempt to artificially extend the playtime.

The gameplay feels similarly dated, as there are no checkpoints. If the levels were shorter, this wouldn't be a problem, but far too often you'll accidentally screw up later in the level, so you'll hit the R button (which you have to find out on your own) only to find yourself back at the beginning, and have to slog through a puzzle you already know how to do but don't move quick enough to do so without getting frustrated.

The price doesn't save a game from not being fun. I know it might seem unfair to keep comparing this to a different game, but I cannot emphasize enough how much better the Karoshi series is at nearly everything Squishy the Suicidal Pig attempts. From the treatment of an inherently messed up subject matter to having to temporarily avoid killing yourself, every single thing in Squishy the Suicidal Pig feels like it's been done better before, and for free.

The one comfort is I've already sold the cards I got from wasting my time on this and gotten my money back.

reviewText:
One thing I want to make clear straight off the bat is that this game gets a positive review from me solely because it is more than worth it's current price of a whopping nine pence. That being said, given that I would probably purchase an empty wrapper that used to contain a chocolate bar and still has some hint of the fragrance for the same price, that's no indication of the game's quality, and to be blunt you can sum up the biggest strength and greatest weakness of the game in one word. Cheap. In both senses of the word.

I don't want to make it sound as if the game is bad - it isn't - but this is an instance where you get what you pay for. Despite the original sounding concept - you need to kill yourself in every level rather than avoid death - it plays ostensibly the same as any other puzzle-platformer; push some boxes, activate some switches, and get to the end. The only difference is that the end of the level is a pit of spikes rather than a princess in a castle.

The controls are simple and not too shabby. Aside from moving and jumping, there's nothing to do. Sure you can walk up to a switch or push a box, but you only need buttons for left, right, and jump. Around 80% of the time the levels are surprisingly decent, showing a good understanding of level design given that your character has barely any abilities. One thing I would improve is the jumping mechanic, as I've died more than a few times due to an unclear cooldown period after jumping during which you can't jump again. That reminds me - every few levels the 'You're trying to die' mechanic is eschewed in favour of finding a key or chasing something, so there are moments when the game loses the biggest asset that was keeping it original.

The other 20% of levels present a pretty big problem though. Some of the levels are ridiculously unclear and downright stupid, and on these levels you won't fail because you lack skill, you'll fail because the game is withholding information you would need to beat it. On one level - and I don't feel the slightest bit guilty about spoiling this - there's a row of pits and two boxes, and the game somehow expects you to figure out that you need to push boxes into pits 4 and 6. There is no indication of this whatsoever, and the closest I could find was a note in the dirt reading 'A-N T-G'. There's leaving things to the player's imagination and then there's just taking liberties.

I'm currently on the Boss of World 2 and I can safely say that as someone who has finished around 75 Steam games, it is the worst boss I've faced in any of them. The arena is small and the boss throws six bombs down, which cover half of the arena. The bombs have a blast radius that is a little over twice their size. Do the math. It doesn't help that to win the battle you need to avoid this attack EIGHTEEN TIMES in a row. That pretty much sums up the worst parts of the game - 10% skill, 90% hoping the random number generator lets you win.

Overall, despite what I've said, this guy is well worth the price. The graphics are pleasant, there's a bit of humour and variety, and although it's hit and miss, there are more hits than misses by far. But bear in mind that if it was priced at say, ¬£5 or more, this would definitely be a negative review. It's fun, but approach with caution.

Unlike 99% of the rest of steam games in this price tier Squishy the Suicidal Pig is well worth the 14 to 99 cent price. It's an unpolished gem with an original concept, a funny story, a unique game mechanic, and a pleasing art style. You can tell the creator actually cared about what they were making. reviewText:
A Hellish puzzle platformer where the objective is to find a way to get yourself killed.
It's relatively short although the difficulty may make you spend a good amount of time trying to get through some really hard levels.
There's levels where you need to stay alive which may be a little confusing when you've been trying desperately to kill yourself, these are generally boss levels which you need to beat instead.

There's not much replay value other than to get any achievements you may have missed if you like collecting them.

It's not something everyone would enjoy as it can be a little frustrating.
The original released version was extremely buggy and left with the developers tools still openly available, it was eventually fully rewritten and fixed most of the issues.

It goes on sale quite often and might be worth grabbing during them, I got it for 95% off and the card drops paid for that so it was practically free. Not something I personally would've bought otherwise but there's nothing I would really complain about after the fix besides the overall difficulty of the game.

Worth trying out if you like a good challenge and got some spare money but probably not worth full price to everyone.

reviewText:
It sounds SO easy: Get yourself killed while platforming.
And it is easy; if you figure out how to do it....

Story
Squishy and his parents are living piggily happy on a farm. Suddenly, his parents get taken away to the slaughterhouse...

Squishy feels very sad and alone, and decides to commit suicide in order to  be reuinited with his parents in heaven.

However: Suicide is a sin, and therefore Squishy ends up in hell instead...

Luckily for him, the devil is bored and makes him a deal: If Squishy loses all his lifes and manages to find the Devil, too, he will be send to his parents in Heaven.

Okay, granted: This story does sound quite dark/grim, but the game itself is quite fun, bright, happy music: For some reason it keeps on reminding me of, for example, Mario 3 on the ancient Snes. The same platforming vibe is going on!

Gameplay/etc.
Because the game looks so overly happy, it looks deceivingly easy: It\s not as easy to get yourself killed as you may think, and in other levels the solution is so easy/obvious you simply don't see it at first, because you start thinking about the other places/stuff the developer placed in that area first.

So, ye: I suppose this might be seen as yet another frustrating. rage invoking, game. And for some reason I just seem to enjoy those games!

Every time I play this game, it hits me how wellmade, pretty, etc. it looks: In my opinion it's worth more as he 0,99 they charge.

reviewText:
It sounds SO easy: Get yourself killed while platforming.
And it is easy; if you figure out how to do it....

Story
Squishy and his parents are living piggily happy on a farm. Suddenly, his parents get taken away to the slaughterhouse...

Squishy feels very sad and alone, and decides to commit suicide in order to  be reuinited with his parents in heaven.

However: Suicide is a sin, and therefore Squishy ends up in hell instead...

Luckily for him, the devil is bored and makes him a deal: If Squishy loses all his lifes and manages to find the Devil, too, he will be send to his parents in Heaven.

Okay, granted: This story does sound quite dark/grim, but the game itself is quite fun, bright, happy music: For some reason it keeps on reminding me of, for example, Mario 3 on the ancient Snes. The same platforming vibe is going on!

Gameplay/etc.
Because the game looks so overly happy, it looks deceivingly easy: It\s not as easy to get yourself killed as you may think, and in other levels the solution is so easy/obvious you simply don't see it at first, because you start thinking about the other places/stuff the developer placed in that area first.

So, ye: I suppose this might be seen as yet another frustrating. rage invoking, game. And for some reason I just seem to enjoy those games!

Price:
I think I got it on a sale some months ago for like 0,15 ct, which looked like a steal.
Every time I play this game, it hits me how wellmade, pretty, etc. it looks: In my opinion it's worth more as he 0,99 they charge.

reviewText:
This is one of the worst games I‚Äôve ever played

Squishy the Suicidal pig looked like a fun ride on paper. It‚Äôs a retroesque puzzle platformer with a unique spin on the conventional view of lives. It looked like something really special.

and then I played it.



The first part of the game is composed of cutscenes that explain the plot. Both the cutscenes and the story itself are awkwardly written. They don‚Äôt really make logical sense. But, hey, this is a platformer so I was cool with it.

The tutorial was nice too, except for the fact that it doesn‚Äôt tell you any of the controls. This is a problem because unless you know going in the spacebar is the action button, it‚Äôs impossible to close out of the signs, effectively making signs death points until you give up and google the controls. I spent 10 minutes trying to beat the level by avoiding every single sign before I realized that it was actually impossible. That‚Äôs 10 minutes of my life that are gone. Forever.

The biggest problem with Squishy, which becomes glaringly apparent as soon as you leave the tutorial, is that you can‚Äôt pull blocks. Or take back mistakes in any way short of full-on restarting the level.

The puzzles in the game aren‚Äôt inherently bad. They‚Äôre actually some of the nicer puzzles I‚Äôve seen. The problem is that you have to solve them with the precision required for open heart surgery.
If you push a block against a wall, you lose. You can‚Äôt complete the puzzle, and you have to restart.
If you push two blocks so close together that you can‚Äôt get in between them, you lose.
If you position a block slightly to the right of where it should be when you blow up a bomb, you lose.
If you do anything even one step out of order or try to solve it in a way even remotely different than the way it was intended, you lose.

It‚Äôs the gameplay equivalent of being hit over the head repeatedly with a hammer. It‚Äôs a memory game, not asking of you your wits but your ability to use trial and error. It asks you of your time, of your willingness to sit there for 20 minutes doing the same puzzle over and over and over again until finally, for reasons beyond your comprehension, you accidentally made the crates line up in the way the dev wanted you to.
And it doesn‚Äôt help that there‚Äôs a grindingly upbeat 10-second loop of music that plays forever, screaming into your soul and reminding you that you, your goals, and your quest are but puffs of smoke in a cold void that doesn‚Äôt care. That nothing you do will ever matter, and that in the end the song will still be there. Still playing. Forever.

There‚Äôs a kind of strange poetry in the way the music and gameplay for this game are compliments to each other. A poetry that you can‚Äôt even think long enough to appreciate while trying to play Squishy the Suicidal Pig.

What irks me the most is how lazy the whole game seems. It‚Äôs like the guy who made this thought up a mildly interesting concept, then thought it was so great that the rest of the game didn‚Äôt even have to be good. The music, the graphics, the character design, everything about this game seems so half-done when you have to sit there staring at it for 5 eternities while you push around crates.

Game developers throughout history have found spectacular ways to engage players and create difficulty in games, be it the puzzles in Portal, the enemy design in Chrono Trigger, or the complex combat situations in Fallout 3. This is the difficulty in Squishy the Suicidal Pig:
http://tinypic.com/r/r9pm5k/8

In hindsight this game is an entirely accurate simulation of the hell it takes place in.
If the developer was trying to simulate the infinite pain and suffering of the burning eternity, I would have given this game 5 stars. Except it‚Äôs blatantly obvious that it wasn‚Äôt intentionally made that way, so it‚Äôs bad.

reviewText:
So, I like to look for Indie Games sometimes, and this game shows potential. You're basically a pig, and the goal of each level is to kill yourself by using various traps.

I have only gotten a little into the game, but here are my thought, as of now.

Pros:
Level Design is unique.
Control is good.
Charming 8-Bit adventure.
Music is upbeat and catchy.
Many fun levels.
Boss Fights!
Many modes, that probaly will make you come back to this game.
OMFG SECRET HATZZZ STORE!!!

Cons:
Restarting a level because of an accidental crate placement is annoying.
Not telling you about different mechanics (Edges of screens are connected.)
Music gets repetative. Fast.
Overall game idea is not that unique.
No button replacement, the arrow keys are your only opition.
Not that many opitions for sound or, anything, really.

Overall, I think this game is good, but not perfect. If you got a few bucks to spend, you like platforming-games or just wanna support Indie Developers, I would recommend this. The game just came out, so maybe some updates will fix the problem with the lack of options. Also, you can't 360 noscope in this game. (Just Kidding! :D)

6 out of 10.

Squishy the Suicidal Pig is a platformer puzzler that despite its simple graphics is super hard
Here is a quick video review and keep reading for more details.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cTUbHDV8onQ&feature=youtu.be

You play a pig in a yellow sweater whose parents went to the slaughter house. Wanting to join them in pig heaven you commit suicide only to find out that it is a one way ticket to hell. Once in hell you make a deal with the devil and now have to die 31 times to get to heaven.

The games concept is really cool. To beat a level you need to kill yourself not survive. Solve the puzzle correctly and you die.

There is a big difference between a hard puzzler and this game. Even is the hardest of puzzlers you can use common sense, deduction and trial and error to finally solve the puzzle.

Squishy the Suicidal Pig says screw that and gives you a game where none of that applies.
Some levels are straightforward and easy. Everything in the level has a purpose and needs to be utilized to beat the level. Then there are other levels that have TNT or giant fans and switched that do absolutely nothing to advance the puzzle and are there just to distract and frustrate. I kid you know after 10 minutes trying to beat a level using every available toy I finally figured it out and that level now takes 5 seconds to beat and I use nothing.

This is a super frustrating game but is addictive and makes you think way way outside of the box. I am enjoying it immensely. I will update this review if anything changes.

It's a shame.  Over the first few levels, the game presents itself as a puzzle platformer that plays against your usual survival instinct in games - don't try to figure out how to finish the level, ignore all that and just concentrate on killing yourself.  Seemed like a great idea that could easily be extrapolated out to 32 more levels, each subverting your expectations on how to 'succeed' in a platform puzzler.

Unfortunately, without any good reason, after six levels it changes all that by introducing a standard platformer section no different to any other game.  Way to destroy your own good idea, developers.

After that, I couldn't be bothered any more.  The aggravating music, which you cannot turn off without disabling sound effects as well; the inability to skip messages when you walk past them; the inaccuracies of the control system - all of that was forgivable when the initial gameplay concept seemed worth pursuing.  When it devolved into a normal, yet substandard, platformer, there was no reason to go on.
